title: Home
text:
Phages are the most abundant and diverse biological entities on the planet. However, our knowledge of them is quite limited. There are currently 27321 phage genomes in the NCBI and this number will continue to grow as researchers produce sequencing data. This website provides an overview of the number of phages and jumbo phages, size, molecule type and host of bacteriophage genomes stored in the NCBI.


The website take advantage of the monthly data set publish by INPHARED. I use the DateMonthYear_data.tsv, to create all plots and calculate the number of phages in the database. If you use the dataset please have a look at their publication.



Currently the website is manually updated each month and depends on the INPHARED dataset. I hope that in the next months I can automate the process.
Last update 2024-03-20

title: Jumbo Phages
text:
Jumbophage genomes
Jumbo phage genomes are around 200kb and currently there are


Show the code
library(tidyverse)
library(plotly)

plot <- read_tsv("rawdata/clean_genomes_data.tsv") %>%
    select(jumbophage) %>%
    count(jumbophage) %>%
    mutate(jumbophage = if_else(jumbophage == FALSE, "No Jumbo Phage",
        "Jumbo Phage"
    )) %>%
    ggplot(aes(
        x = jumbophage,
        y = n
    )) +
    geom_col() +
    scale_y_continuous(
        expand = c(0, 0),
        limits = c(0, 30000),
        breaks = seq(0, 300000, 3000)
    ) +
    labs(
        x = NULL,
        y = "Number of phages"
    ) +
    theme(
        text = element_text(size = 15, family = "Cabin Sketch"),
        panel.background = element_blank(),
        panel.border = element_rect(colour = "black", fill = NA, linewidth = 2)
    )

ggplotly(plot)

title: Home
text: Hi my name is Johan Sebastián Sáenz and I am a microbial ecologist currently working in the Department of Functional Microbiology of Livestock at the Hohenheim University. I am interested in the main drivers of microbial community structure and function, with special focus on the phage’s role.
